summary: This document is an email chain from September 2020 between FBI personnel discussing the Office of Professional Responsibility's (OPR) draft report on the Southern District of Florida's handling of the Jeffrey Epstein investigation from 2006-2008. The FBI is conducting a sensitivity review to ensure the report's release does not impact their legal position under '7A' (likely a reference to Title 7A or a specific legal stance).

persons.name: Special Agent - FBI New York Field Office
persons.context: Recipient of an email forwarding the OPR report for review regarding the Epstein investigation. States it's the first time they've seen it and will read through it.

connections.person1: Special Agent - FBI New York Field Office
connections.description: Both are FBI personnel involved in the internal review and coordination regarding the OPR report on the Epstein investigation.

events.title: Epstein Investigation by Southern District of Florida

events.title: OPR Transmits Draft Report to FBI
events.description: The Department of Justice Office of Professional Responsibility sends a draft report and a transmittal letter to the FBI's Office of General Counsel for a sensitivity review.

events.title: FBI Internal Review of OPR Report
events.description: FBI personnel in New York and other units are reviewing the OPR draft report to assess if its release would impact the FBI's '7A' legal stance, with a deadline to respond.

locations: U.S. Department of Justice, 950 Pennsylvania Avenue, N.W. â€” Room 3266, Washington, D.C. 20530
keyFacts: The Department of Justice's Office of Professional Responsibility (OPR) completed a draft report investigating the Southern District of Florida's handling of the Jeffrey Epstein case from 2006-2008.

In September 2020, the FBI's Office of General Counsel was conducting a confidential sensitivity review of the OPR draft report to ensure it would not impact the FBI's legal position (referred to as '7A').
The email chain reveals internal FBI coordination and a tight deadline (within about a week) to complete the review and respond to OPR.
The document references the report being too large to email and being sent in two parts, indicating a substantial investigation into prosecutorial conduct.
